com.kdgregory.kdgcommons.lang

Class StringUtil

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.kdgregory.kdgcommons.lang.StringUtil

  • public class StringUtil
extends Object
    A collection of static utility functions for working with Strings. All are null-safe: in general they treat null as an empty string (see JavaDoc for any differences).

    • Method Summary

      Tests for equality, where null is equivalent to an empty string.

      Returns a substring of the source string, from its start up to but not including the first occurrence of the target string.

        public static int length(String str)
        Returns the length of the passed string, 0 if the string is null.
        Since:

        public static boolean equalOrEmpty(String s1,
                                   String s2)
        Tests for equality, where null is equivalent to an empty string.

        Returns the last character in the passed string, '\0' if passed null or an empty string.

      • isEmpty

        public static boolean isEmpty(String str)
        Determines whether the passed string is null or zero length.

      • isBlank

        public static boolean isBlank(String str)
        Determines whether the passed string is null, empty, or contain only whitespace (as determined by java.lang.Character).

      • trim

        public static String trim(String str)
        Removes all whitespace characters from either side of a string, using Character.isWhitespace() to test. Returns an empty string if passed null, the original string if it doesn't need trimming.

      • trimToNull

        public static String trimToNull(String str)
        Invokes trim(java.lang.String), and returns null if the result is an empty string This is useful to create flag values.
        Since:
        1.0.9

      • padLeft

        public static String padLeft(String str,
                             int len,
                             char c)
        Pads a string that is < N characters by adding the specified character on the left side. Treats null as a zero-length string (ie, returned string will just consist of padding).

      • padRight

        public static String padRight(String str,
                              int len,
                              char c)
        Pads a string that is < N characters by adding the specified character on the right side. Treats null as a zero-length string (ie, returned string will just consist of padding).

      • contains

        public static boolean contains(String str,
                               String segment)
        Determines whether the first string contains the second.

        Returns true if the second string is an empty string or the two strings are equal. Returns false if either of the strings are null. Does not care how many times the second string appears in the first; only that it appears.

      • containsIgnoreCase

        public static boolean containsIgnoreCase(String str,
                                         String segment)
        Determines whether the first string contains the second, ignoring case of individual letters.

        Returns true if the second string is an empty string or the two strings are equal. Returns false if either of the strings are null. Does not care how many times the second string appears in the first; only that it appears.

      • repeat

        public static String repeat(char c,
                            int count)
        Creates a string that consists of a single character, repeated N times.

      • toUTF8

        public static byte[] toUTF8(String str)
        Converts the string to a UTF-8 byte array, turning the checked exception (which should never happen) into a runtime exception. Returns an empty array if passed null.

        Note: as of JDK 1.7, you can call String.getBytes() with an enum from java.nio.charset.StandardCharsets. This function is still useful if you want a null-safe converstion.

      • fromUTF8

        public static String fromUTF8(byte[] bytes)
        Converts the passed byte array to a string, using UTF-8 encoding, and turning the checked exception (which should never happen) into a runtime exception. If passed null, returns an empty string.

        Note: as of JDK 1.7, you can call new String() with an enum from java.nio.charset.StandardCharsets. This function is still useful if you want a null-safe converstion.

      • unicodeEscape

        public static String unicodeEscape(String src)
        Escapes the passed string, replacing all characters outside the range 32..126, as well as quotes and backslashes, with unicode escapes. This is useful for strings written by a code generator.

        If passed null, returns null.

      • unescape

        public static String unescape(String src)
        Un-escapes the passed string, replacing the standard slash escapes with their corresponding unicode character value.

      • parseDigit

        public static int parseDigit(char c,
                             int base)
        Parses the passed character as a digit in the specified base, returning its value. Bases > 10 are represented by ASCII letters in the range A to Z (or a to z). Base 36 is the largest supported.
        Returns:
        The value, or -1 if the character is not a valid digit in the specified base (this method will typically be used in a loop, so no good reason to force exception checking).

      • randomString

        public static String randomString(String chars,
                                  int minLength,
                                  int maxLength)
        Generates a (non-cryptographicaly) random string consisting of characters from the passed string. Useful for generating bogus string fields.

        Warning: not threadsafe; uses a shared instance of java.util.Random.

        Parameters:
        chars - Defines the set of characters used to create the returned string.
        minLength - Minimum length of the returned string.
        maxLength - Maximum length of the returned string.

      • randomAlphaString

        public static String randomAlphaString(int minLength,
                                       int maxLength)
        Generates a string containing (non-cryptographicaly-) random ASCII alphabetic characters (A-Za-z). Useful for generating bogus string fields.

        Warning: not threadsafe; uses a shared instance of java.util.Random.

        Parameters:
        minLength - Minimum length of the returned string.
        maxLength - Maximum length of the returned string.

      • extractLeft

        public static String extractLeft(String source,
                                 String target)
        Returns a substring of the source string, from its start up to but not including the first occurrence of the target string. If the target does not exist in the source, returns the source string. If the source or target strings are null, they are treated as empty strings (and an empty target will not exist in the source).

        This method is used to divide a string based on an optional delimiter; for example, dividing "host:port" at ":".

        See also extractLeftOfLast(java.lang.String, java.lang.String).

        Since:
        1.0.6

      • extractRight

        public static String extractRight(String source,
                                  String target)
        Returns a substring of the source string, from immediately after the first occurrence of the target string, to the end of the source. If the target does not exist in the source, returns an empty string. If the source or target strings are null, they are treated as empty strings (and an empty target will not exist in the source).

        This method is used to divide a string based on an optional delimiter; for example, dividing "host:port" at ":".

        See also extractRightOfLast(java.lang.String, java.lang.String).

        Since:
        1.0.6

      • extractLeftOfLast

        public static String extractLeftOfLast(String source,
                                       String target)
        Returns a substring of the source string, from its start up to but not including the last occurrence of the target string. If the target does not exist in the source, returns the source string. If the source or target strings are null, they are treated as empty strings (and an empty target will not exist in the source).

        This method is used to incrementally partition a string, for example, extracting components from a filepath (eg: "/foo/bar/baz.txt", with a target of "/" results in "/foo/bar").

        See also extractLeft(java.lang.String, java.lang.String).

        Since:
        1.0.6

      • extractRightOfLast

        public static String extractRightOfLast(String source,
                                        String target)
        Returns a substring of the source string, from immediately after the last occurrence of the target string, to the end of the source. If the target does not exist in the source, returns an empty string. If the source or target strings are null, they are treated as empty strings (and an empty target will not exist in the source).

        This method is used to incrementally partition a string, for example, extracting components from a filepath (eg: "/foo/bar/baz.txt", with a target of "/" results in "baz.txt").

        See also extractRight(java.lang.String, java.lang.String).

        Since:
        1.0.6

      • substr

        public static String substr(String src,
                            int off,
                            int len)
        A flexible substring that is null-safe, can return left or right substrings, and is not constrained to the boundaries of the original string.

        When identifying a the range of characters to return, this function behaves as if the string is extended in both directions with "non-characters." The starting and ending offsets may point into these extended areas. However, the only characters returned will be those from the actual string.

        Examples:

        • substr("foo", 0, 2) is "fo"
        • substr("foo", 1, 1000) is "oo"
        • substr("foo", 999, 1000) is ""
        • substr("foo", -1, 2) is "o"
        • substr("foo", -3, 2) is "fo"
        • substr("foo", -3, 17) is "foo"
        Parameters:
        src - The source string; null is treated as an empty string.
        off - The starting offset of the substring. If negative, offset is measured from the end of the string (where -1 is the last character).
        len - The maximum number of characters to retrieve from the string.
        Returns:
        A string containing up to len characters.
        Since:
        1.0.15

      • isIn

        public static boolean isIn(String str,
                           String... targets)
        Returns true if the passed string is equal to one of the target strings, false otherwise. This will typically be invoked with a variable str and literal values for target.
        Since:
        1.0.6

      • valueOf

        public static String valueOf(Object obj)
        A replacement for String.valueOf() that returns an empty string for null.
        Since:
        1.0.14
